title: The Leaning Tower of Pisa's Rescue
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Leaning Tower of Pisa's Rescue.

hook.text: The Leaning Tower of Pisa started tilting during construction in 1173. It took 800 years to figure out a fix.

buildup.text: Soft clay on one side of the foundation compressed more than the other, causing the tower to lean almost immediately.

discovery.text: Medieval builders tried to correct it by making upper floors taller on the leaning sideâ€”giving the tower a banana curve.

twist.text: By 1990 the lean hit 5.5 degrees and closure loomed. Engineers extracted soil from the high side to straighten it.

climax.text: The tower now leans at a stable 3.97 degreesâ€”enough to thrill tourists but safe for another 200 years.

punchline.text: They saved it by making the other side sink.

quiz.question: How did engineers stabilize the Leaning Tower of Pisa?
options: They extracted soil from the side opposite the lean
They added concrete weights to the leaning side
They installed steel cables to pull it straight
